summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner requesting that the OCME withhold from disclosure certain materials and information related to the autopsy and investigation of Jeffrey Epstein's death, to avoid compromising the ongoing criminal investigation into his suicide.

persons.name: Florence Butner
persons.role: General Counsel, Office of the Chief Medical Examiner
persons.context: Recipient of the letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office, addressed in her capacity as General Counsel for the OCME regarding the handling of Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy materials.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the autopsy and the ongoing criminal investigation into his suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed the letter, representing the office conducting the investigation.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is formally corresponding with Butner, as OCME General Counsel, to make legal requests regarding the handling of investigation materials.
Berman's office is conducting the criminal investigation into the circumstances of Epstein's death.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide

events.title: DOJ Letter to OCME
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends a formal letter to the OCME requesting non-disclosure of investigation materials related to Epstein's autopsy.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI were conducting an ongoing criminal investigation into the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's suicide on August 10, 2019.
The OCME had been given access to investigation materials between August 10 and August 16, 2019, to assist in determining the cause and manner of Epstein's death.

The DOJ formally requested the OCME withhold from any third party all documents, evidence, or information provided by the USAO or FBI, including MCC records and OCME files containing that information.
The request also included withholding the names and statements of any federal law enforcement agents or employees interviewed by the OCME.
